website_summaries.verdict: Though not ideal for all climates or soil types, in the right conditions Texas bluebonnets are both gorgeous and practical and are likely to last throughout the growing season.
pros: Produces vibrant blue flowers that are known to attract pollinators that are beneficial to gardens, including bees and hummingbirds
Hardy, long-lasting, and beautiful when in bloom
cons: Ideal germination requires specific conditions, including a sunny area with well-drained soil
Rare reports of packages arriving with fewer than 1,000 seeds

customer_reviews.title: Seed Needs - beautiful seeds, great service
customer_reviews.text: We are so pleased to have found Seed Needs and were able to purchase a large quantity of bluebonnet seeds. We recently found out that our yearly planting of bluebonnets has earned us the name of 'The Bluebonnet House' in our subdivision. Over 150 homes flooded in our subdivision, so we felt we really had to go all out this spring in an effort to bring normalcy back. Seed Needs had the bulk seeds we needed, and they arrived in just a few days, perfect for our usual planting day. We will definitely use this supplier from now on. PEK from Texas
customer_reviews.author: PEK from TX

customer_reviews.title: They're sprouting!
customer_reviews.text: Every seed in the packet was definitely a bluebonnet seed, no fillers here! I froze them overnight and then poured near boiling water over them and allowed them to soak several hours. I then dried them off with a paper towel, many had plumped up already, and scattered them onto my prepared soil. I raked soil over them then walked on them to press the. In. I watered them the next couple of days and within about five to seven days noticed the sprouts coming up. They will continue to grow through the winter and in early Spring I hope to see blue everywhere. These seeds are good to grow no doubt!
customer_reviews.author: Michael J. Griffin

customer_reviews.title: This was a decent price for a good size package of bluebonnet seeds
customer_reviews.text: This was a decent price for a good size package of bluebonnet seeds. I planted in late October. Given the weather we've been having (a very spring like fall), my seeds already started growing. I'm excited and sad. Hopefully they won't freeze over the winter, but luckily many have already started sprouting from the package I received.
customer_reviews.author: Katie C

customer_reviews.title: Did not germinate- possible user error
customer_reviews.text: Sooo....it doesn’t seem like any of these seeds germinated. 😢 But I would like to add that I also planted many packets of mixed wildflower seeds- which included bluebonnets (supposedly). Out of a million billion seeds, I’ve only spotted TWO definite bluebonnet plants. Bear in mind these are WILD flowers and it’s difficult to make them do what you want. I would recommend maybe cold stratifying them or scoring them before planting (which I didn’t do) to increase your chances of success.
customer_reviews.author: moxycat

customer_reviews.title: Beautiful Texas Bluebonnets
customer_reviews.text: Fantastic seeds! I never know how the highway department gets bluebonnets to grow so easy on the roadsides, because I always have a difficult time getting them to take hold. But these seeds are coming up the first year. I planted them in the fall with only compost and they are just starting to pop (March 15th). I will definitely order them again next fall to add to my yard.
customer_reviews.author: Mary Beth Goodwin

customer_reviews.title: They have to stay inside for awhile but hopefully she can transplant them outside for everyone to enjoy. Very happy
customer_reviews.text: I sent these seeds to a native Texan living in another " world" called Ohio🙂. She was missing home (Texas, of course) , so I sent her these bluebonnet seeds to help cheer her up. She prepared the seeds, then was up every morning to see if they popped their heads through the soil. It took a couple of weeks ( too cold in Ohio) then " YES" THERE WERE BLUEBONNETS IN OHIO!! She is thrilled to see them. They have to stay inside for awhile but hopefully she can transplant them outside for everyone to enjoy. Very happy!!
customer_reviews.author: Jan

customer_reviews.title: Very easy instructions
customer_reviews.text: Product arrived quickly. I was able to plant the seeds with no issues per the easy instructions provided on the package- I have a large field behind our home that needed a strong hearty plant. I live in an semi arrid area of the country. I have my fingers crossed that after we go through a winter cycle, the flowers will come in strong.
customer_reviews.author: spamola

customer_reviews.title: Great Privately Owned Seed Company!!
customer_reviews.text: Not only is it difficult to find non-GMO seeds, but it can be really difficult to find seeds produced by privately owned farms rather than large agricultural corporations that appear to be small businesses. Seed Needs is a privately owned farm with non-GMO seeds. Not only that, the seeds and their packaging are GREAT!! They also came quickly and propagated well. I highly recommend Seed Needs!!
customer_reviews.author: Janna Charlton

customer_reviews.title: As Described
customer_reviews.text: As most gardeners know it will be awhile before the bluebonnets show their colors. I can say though that the packaging was very nice and there were a great many seeds ( I didn't count them ). Really looking forward to them blooming since all of our other wildflowers are doing great.
customer_reviews.author: Maureen Mercer Wali

customer_reviews.title: so pretty cool. I also send them photos of the ...
customer_reviews.text: Use these seeds as gifts for clients who happen to visit our Plant here in Freeport, Texas. Many of the customers plant them when they have returned home and seen a crop the next spring. so pretty cool. I also send them photos of the Hill Country in the Spring just to whet their whistles!

customer_reviews.title: Every seed is different, you never what you’ll get.
customer_reviews.text: As right now my review will be based off of the time it took to receive the seeds and the amount of viable seeds thus far. Overall 30 out of 1,000 seeds were not viable. Tested with the water method. Which ever ones float will most likely not germinate. The true test is yet to come. I will up date my review when I see sprouts! Fingers crossed. I live in deep east Texas where blue bonnets grow wild so my hopes are pretty high.
customer_reviews.author: Kelsey

customer_reviews.title: Seeds looked good
customer_reviews.text: I purchased these seeds a few weeks ago. I was impressed enough with the quality of how they looked to make an additional purchase a few days later. While I didn't count the seeds, there were a LOT of them and they covered a nice area. I recognize that I waited until late to plant them, but I wanted to give it a go and try. Wish me luck!

customer_reviews.title: I do however anticipate a beautiful blanket of Blue Bonnets
customer_reviews.text: Only a three star at this time as I do appreciate the quick response to questions I have had regarding the storing of the seeds. The seeds will not be planted until the fall of 2018 thus not being in bloom until the spring of 2019; I do however anticipate a beautiful blanket of Blue Bonnets. I do reserve the right to add stars later.

customer_reviews.title: Great results, buying again.

I scarified mine and this year I have many, many plants up in places I spread this seed but didn’t have bluebonnets in the past so I know they came up from this batch. Also, for those who thought they got slighted on amount - mine had 1,018 seeds - don’t think you could realistically come closer than that. Am buying more to spread for next year as this is clearly a better idea than waiting for Mother Nature.

product_meta.title: Seed Needs, Texas Bluebonnet (Lupinus texenis) 1,000 Seeds Bulk
product_meta.description: Grow Texas Bluebonnet from fresh Lupinus texensis flower seeds. Texas Bluebonnet is a biennial flowering plant that was selected to become the state flower of Texas in 1905. They produce stunning, deep blue or indigo colored blooms. Each Texas Bluebonnet plant grows to a mature height of 8 to 12 inches tall, displaying rows of flowers along it's stems. The tops of these flowers are often times white to pale yellow. Texas Bluebonnet, as well as other Lupinus flowers are known to attract an array of beneficial insects, such as butterflies, bumblebees, ladybugs & hummingbirds as well. Texas Bluebonnets are best sown in masses for an amazing sea of colorful, deep blue blooms that last through the summer months. The seeds appear as small rocks or gravel, and can be a bit tricky to germinate. However, with the proper technique, you will be able to grow Texas Bluebonnet from seed with no issue at all.
feature_bullets: Quality Texas Bluebonnet seeds packaged by Seed Needs. Intended for the current and the following growing season. Packets are 3.25" wide by 4.50" tall and come with a full colored illustration on the front side, as well as detailed sowing instructions on the reverse.
Texas Bluebonnet is a biennial flowering plant that was selected to become the state flower of Texas in 1905.

They produce stunning, deep blue or indigo colored blooms. Each Texas Bluebonnet plant grows to a mature height of 8 to 12 inches tall, displaying rows of flowers along it's stems. The tops of these flowers are often times white to pale yellow.

Texas Bluebonnet, as well as other Lupinus flowers are known to attract an array of beneficial insects, such as butterflies, bumblebees, ladybugs & hummingbirds as well. Texas Bluebonnets are best sown in masses for an amazing sea of colorful, deep blue blooms that last through the summer months.

All Texas Bluebonnet seeds sold by Seed Needs are Non-GMO based seed products and are intended for the current & the following growing season. All seeds are produced from open pollinated plants, stored in a temperature controlled facility and constantly moved out due to popularity.
